text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two columns of text with a large historiated miniature inserted in the lower left of the left column; a historiated initial begins the right column; margins on all sides populated by a continuous vine-scroll border bearing foliate motifs, grotesque animals and human drolleries. Text is arranged in regular, justified columns with red rubrics and line-fillers; wide outer and bottom margins accommodate playful marginal figures without interrupting columnar text.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with consistent stroke thickness, precise angularity, extensive use of standard medieval abbreviations and ligatures, rubrication in red for stanza initials

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for important decorative elements (background of miniature, initials, border bezants) and highlights on armor; ultramarine blue and vermillion alternate on initials and line-fillers to establish visual rhythm; green is applied sparingly in border foliage; white highlights accent folds in drapery and armor reflections. The pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening of white and no significant oxidation of blues.

features: Enthroned monarch rendered larger and centrally positioned within canopy frame
Group of kneeling knights in graduated scale behind principal supplicant
Architectural canopy with pinnacles establishes focal point
Flat patterned gold background emphasizes figure-ground separation
Symmetrical arrangement of attendant figures flanking central axis

decorative_elements: Continuous vine-scroll border with acanthus leaves and gold bezants
Grotesque animals (rabbits, dogs) perched on border
Human drolleries performing acrobatics in lower margin
Historiated initial with interlaced foliage and a standing figure
Micro-architectural canopy framing the throne in the miniature

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with controlled variation in line weight for figure contours and drapery
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color blocking with minimal hatching, white lead highlights on folds and armor to suggest volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of figures by importance, overlapping but no systematic linear perspective, ground plane indicated by patterned tile only

sub_themes: Political messages: feudal hierarchy and homage ceremony
Cultural references: contemporary knightly costume and court ritual
Social context: ceremonial vassalage before a crowned sovereign
content_theme.scene_description: A single courtly ceremony: at left under a Gothic micro-architectural canopy sits a crowned monarch wearing a red robe with gold trim and holding a sceptre, his feet on a patterned dais. Facing him to the right is a kneeling nobleman in a blue tunic and chausses, hands joined in supplication. Behind the kneeling figure stand six armored knights in silver and blue surcoats bearing heraldic shields, plumed helmets at their feet, in two rows diminishing in scale. The figures occupy a gold diapered background. The canopy’s pinnacles echo the vine-scroll border. Floor tiles in alternating red and white establish a ground plane. Costumes include cloth-of-gold trim, fur-lined cloaks on the monarch, and steel mail coifs on the knights. Shields display simple geometric heraldry. Facial features are lightly modeled with white highlights. The central action emphasizes feudal loyalty; attendant knights observe in deference. Secondary Elements: A full-page vine border of acanthus leaves and gold bezants frames the scene; grotesque animals and human drolleries enliven margins. Symbolic Components: Crown and sceptre denote royal authority; heraldic shields identify noble status. Compositional Focus: The enthroned king occupies the visual apex, balanced by the line of kneeling and standing figures leading the viewer’s eye across the miniature.

secular: Enthroned monarch in red robe and fur-lined cloak
Kneeling noble in blue tunic and chausses
Group of armored knights with surcoats and shields
Marginal acrobatic figures (children and adults performing handstands and carrying each other)

architectural: Gothic canopy with pinnacles framing throne
Patterned floor tiles in front of throne

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, uniformly thin and cream-colored, with smooth surface preparation, professional plummet ruling visible under UV
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent: vivid ultramarine and gold remain lustrous; minor flaking of vermillion in high-relief areas; very slight cockling at edges but no significant staining
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso relief beneath gold leaf in miniature and initials
Underdrawing visible in brown ink beneath border foliage under infrared
Regular ruling lines for text layout exhibited under raking light
Fine punchwork dot pattern in gold background fields

functional_analysis.primary_function: Entertainment (illustrated chivalric romance or historical chronicle)
secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth and refinement
Memory aid for reciting or performing the text
Demonstration of courtly ideals and feudal loyalty

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This leaf exemplifies a mid-14th-century Parisian workshop’s mastery of secular illumination in the service of courtly literature. Executed on fine calf vellum with professional textura quadrata, the page integrates a single, hierarchically scaled historical scene—likely depicting a feudal homage rite—within a richly detailed border of gold bezants and lively drolleries. The prominence of ultramarine and burnished gold, along with precise gesso relief and punchwork, reflects the high cost of materials and the patron’s status. The historiated initial and miniature share a vocabulary of micro-architectural canopies and patterned backgrounds common to the Parisian illuminators of the period, suggesting influence from the Jean Pucelle circle and the evolving International Gothic style. Iconographically, the crowned sovereign and kneeling vassal enact a visual assertion of feudal order, while the heraldic shields and contemporary armature anchor the scene in a recognizable aristocratic milieu. Marginal figures performing acrobatics introduce a humorous counterpoint, characteristic of secular manuscripts intended for private enjoyment rather than liturgical use. Comparatively, the page bears affinities with the so-called ‘Tournoi Book’ of Charles V, though its freer border treatment indicates a workshop experimenting beyond rigid royal commissions. Overall, the leaf bridges traditional hierarchical composition with innovative marginal playfulness, marking a transitional moment in Gothic illumination.
